Award.AwardTitle: Statistical Analysis of High Dimensional Manifold Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
Manifold-valued data appear frequently in shape and image analysis, computer vision, biomechanics and many others. Medical imaging data in studies of the variability of human organ shapes lie on a fairly high dimensional nonlinear manifolds, where the challenge is two-fold: high dimensionality with a low sample size (data are expensive to gather) and naturally imposed non-Euclidean geometry. The proposed research aims to answer scientific questions arising in object shape analysis and to provide solid mathematical basis for more complex problems. First, the investigator takes and extends the strategy of backward dimension reduction with regularization framework. Sparse representation of shape and directional data are proposed and their properties are studied. In the regression context, polynomial regression for manifold-valued response to model and test non-geodesic trends is proposed. An extension of local polynomial modeling is also considered. The investigator also explores efficient computational methods.

The study of object shape is crucial for understanding the population of human anatomical objects and revealing the interplay between biomarkers/clinical outcomes and object shape variations. Due to the advanced technology, the modern object shape data become big and complex, but conventional methods lack considerations on the special geometric structure of the data types. This research project aims to provide new statistical methodologies for exploratory and confirmatory analysis of the large-scale non-standard data types, including the object shapes. The project will also produce statistical tools, which may be applied in many fields including biomechanics, computer vision, medical studies and biological sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the NSF-awarded project on “Statistical Analysis of High Dimensional Manifold Data,” new theoretical and methodological advances were made to statistical analysis of modern complex data. In particular, we developed methods to reveal main patterns among populations of 2D and 3D shapes, objects and images. At the data exploration stage of analysis, the main patterns are usually revealed by various means of dimension reduction.

We created a new family of probability distributions to model rotational deformations of 3D shapes that enable testing of geometric hypotheses regarding human movement and internal organ shapes. These can be used eventually in disease diagnostics. The new models are related to a family of dimension-reduction models for high-dimensional directional data, which also indicates a potential model-based dimension reduction of data sets of 2D shapes.

For interpretable analysis of diffusion tensor images, a measure of brain functionality, we extend the rotation-scaling framework and carefully laid out mathematical and geometrical foundations for statistics. It is shown in the context of diffusion tensor analysis and fiber tracking, the newly developed framework provides the estimation of natural and interpretable fibers, to which all previous methods failed. The geometrical foundations are a key in the development of more sophisticated statistical analysis.

Moreover, we translated the techniques developed for manifold data analysis to other complex data analysis, leading to methodologies for classification of sets and multi-source data factorization. With the surge of big data, more observations of various types are becoming increasingly gathered. The new data analysis techniques are just a few attempts to answer the major underlying question: how to collect meaningful information from a large, noise-filled, data set.
